Compiled by Monk Zhishi of Xichongfu Temple in the Gengwu Year
The reason for the creation of catalogs is precisely to distinguish true from false, clarify right from wrong, and record the ancient and modern generations of people.
It marks the number of scrolls and sections.
It collects the missing, deletes the redundant, and eliminates the superfluous.
It aims to make the correct teachings have a coherent structure and the golden words have a sequence.
It lifts up the main points and essentials, which can be clearly seen.
However, the Dharma gate is profound and the net of transformation is vast.
The translations from the past have changed over the years.
It has been destroyed many times, with scrolls and chapters mixed up.
Moreover, different people have added false and deceptive [texts] from time to time.
This has caused confusion and difficulty in tracing the origins.
Therefore, the sages and virtuous ones of the past have compiled these catalogs.
There are now about six or seven extant ones.
However, they still have not reached the root source and are still lacking in many ways.
Zhishi, with his mediocrity, has long been studying and searching.
He has examined the differences and pointed out the right and wrong.
Thus completing this collection.
Hopefully avoiding contradictions.
I hope the wise will all look over it together.
I bow my head to the well-gone, the venerable sage, the unsurpassed hero, the tamer of men.
I also pay homage to the pure and wondrous Dharma of the Three Vehicles, as well as to the Sangha of the eight classes of noble ones.
I compose this catalog of scriptures to protect the Dharma city. May the Three Jewels, out of compassion, secretly assist me.
I only pray that the Dharma lamp will illuminate the long night, and that the deluded will thereby attain the wisdom-light.
May the true Dharma long abide in the world, and those who rely on it will quickly ascend to the unsurpassed stage.

He was the crown prince of the legitimate queen of the king of Arsakes.ğŸ”½From a young age, he was pure and filial, revering and nurturing with utmost sincerity.
His compassion extended even to the lowly creatures.
His actions and conduct were as if treading on a ruler and square.
Moreover, his aspirations and undertakings were intelligent, and he was determined to love learning.
There were no non-Buddhist scriptures that he did not encompass.
The images of the seven luminaries and the five elements,
The divination of wind, horns, clouds, and objects,
The expansion and contraction of the steps, all exhausted their changes.
In addition, he thoroughly understood medical techniques and was skilled in acupuncture and moxibustion.
Seeing the colors, he knew the illness, and the medicine he prescribed was sure to cure it.
Even the cries of birds and beasts, hearing their voices, he knew their thoughts.
Once while walking, he saw a flock of birds and suddenly said to his companion,
He said, There should be someone who brings food.
Soon, there really was someone who brought it.
The assembly all marveled at this. Thus, his name of outstanding difference was known in the Western Regions.
The neighboring countries far and near all respected and admired him.
Although Gao was living at home, he upheld the precepts with utmost strictness.
He lectured on the Dharma and gave teachings continuously with the times.
Later, when the king passed away, he was about to succeed to the throne.
He deeply contemplated the suffering and emptiness, and became disgusted with fame and status.
After the mourning period was over, he abdicated the throne to his uncle and left home to cultivate the Way.
He extensively studied the Buddhist canon and was especially proficient in the Abhidharma teachings.
He recited the meditation sutras and roughly mastered their subtleties.
Then, he traveled around to spread the teachings, visiting various countries.
In the beginning of Emperor Huan's reign of the Han dynasty, he arrived in the Eastern Xia (China).
Gao was talented, insightful, and quick-witted. He could understand after hearing something once.
Before long, he mastered the spoken language of the Great Tang (China).
He lamented the decline of the true Dharma and extensively engaged in translation work.
Gao thoroughly understood the principles of nature and was self-aware of his past causes and conditions.
There were many miraculous traces, which the world could not fathom.
Gao first called himself a prince of Arsakes in his previous life.
He left home together with the son of an elder in his country.
When they were begging for alms,
they encountered a donor who did not meet their expectations.ğŸ”½Gao often felt resentful.
Gao repeatedly admonished him,
but he still did not reform.
In this way, for more than twenty years.
He then took leave of his fellow student, saying,
I will go to Guangzhou to end the karmic retribution from my past lives.
You are diligent in studying the scriptures and are not inferior to me,
but you have a lot of anger.
After your death, you will receive an evil form.
If I attain enlightenment, I will definitely save you.ğŸ”½After that, he went to Guangzhou.
When he arrived, the region was in great turmoil due to bandits.
While traveling, he encountered a young man
who spat out his hand, drew his sword and said, I have finally found you!
Gao laughed and said,
I owe you from my past life, so I have come from afar to repay you.
Your anger
is the same intention as in your previous life.
He then extended his neck to receive the blade, his expression showing no fear.
The bandits then killed him.
Spectators filled the road.
None were not amazed by his strangeness.
And this consciousness returned to become the crown prince of the King of Arsakes.
This is now the body of Shi Hu.
Hu traveled and spread the teachings in China, completing the task of propagating the sutras.
At the end of the reign of Emperor Ling, there was turmoil in Guanzhong and Luoyang.
He then shook his staff and said he would go south of the Yangtze River, saying:
I will pass by Mount Lu to save my former classmates.
He arrived at the temple of the Lake of the Cauldron.
This temple had long been revered as a spiritual place.
Merchants and travelers prayed to it, and then they would be divided into boats going up and down the river, without any delays.
Once someone asked to borrow bamboo from the god.
Without permission, he took it.
The boat immediately capsized.
The bamboo returned to its original place.
From then on, boatmen respected and feared it, and no one dared to offend it.
Hu's group of over thirty boats offered sacrifices and prayed for blessings.
The god then descended and said:
There is a monk on the boat. Call him up.
The guests were all shocked and asked Gao to enter the temple.
The spirit told Gao:
In the past, in a foreign country, we both left home to study the Way.
We liked to practice giving but had a lot of anger. Now we are the temple spirit of Quting.
Within a radius of a thousand li, it is all under our rule.
Because of our giving, we have many precious and wonderful things.
Because of our anger, we have fallen into this divine retribution.
Now seeing my former classmate, I am both sad and happy.
My life is coming to an end.
But my ugly form is tall and large.
If I abandon my life here, it will defile the rivers and lakes.
I should cross the mountains to the west and enter the marshes.
After this body perishes, I fear I will fall into hell.
I have a thousand bolts of silk and various precious things.
You can use them to establish a Dharma and build a stupa to make me be reborn in a good place.
Gao said:
I came here on purpose to save you. Why don't you show your form?
The spirit said:
My form is very ugly and strange. Many people will surely be afraid.
Gao said:
Just show yourself. The crowd will not be surprised.
The spirit stuck its head out from behind the bed.
It was a huge python.
I do not know the length of its tail.
It reached up to my knees.
I chanted the Sanskrit verses and praises several times.
The python shed tears like rain and soon disappeared.
I then took the silk and said goodbye, leaving.
The boat crew raised the sails.
The python again showed its body, climbed the mountain, and looked at the group of people.
It waved its hand and then disappeared.
In a short while, we arrived at Yuzhang.
I used the temple offerings to build a temple in the east.
After I left, the deity immediately passed away.
In the evening, a young man
knelt before the boat and me.
He received my vows and suddenly disappeared.
I told the boatmen:
